recipes.title: Cheesy curried butter beans on toast with pickled onion
recipes.description: Beans on toast, all grown up. This makes the perfect lunch-al-desko for those who work from home, but also a great quick and easy dinner for adults and kids alike (serve the pickle on the side, if you like). Play around with different canned beans, cheeses, and herbs here, using up what you can nd in your pantry and fridge.

¼ cup/5g fresh cilantro, roughly chopped

1 serrano chile, thinly sliced into rounds, seeds and all (⅓ oz/10g)
½ red onion, peeled and thinly sliced into rounds (2¼ oz/60g)

instructions: 1. Preheat the oven broiler to high.
2. Make the pickled onion. Put the serrano chile, onion, vinegar, and a tiny pinch of salt into a small bowl and mix to combine. Set aside to soften and pickle while you continue with the rest. ½

3. Heat 1 tablespoons of the oil in a medium sauté pan on medium-high heat. Cook the ginger and garlic until lightly golden and fragrant, stirring – often, 2 3 minutes. Add the spices and cook for 30 seconds before stirring in ¼ the butter beans, teaspoon of salt, and plenty of black pepper. Remove – from the heat and set aside to cool slightly, 5 10 minutes. Once cool, stir in the cilantro, cream, and cheese.

4. Place the bread on a small baking sheet and broil for 2 minutes. Remove from the oven, ip over, and drizzle the untoasted sides with the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil. Top each with the butter bean mixture and return to the – oven broiler for 4 5 minutes, or until golden and bubbly.

5. To serve, spoon half the pickled onion mixture over the top, serving the rest in a bowl alongside. Pickled onion – – Make 2 3 times the amount of pickled onions, minus the chile, and keep refrigerated in a sterilized jar for up to 2 weeks. – These go particularly well tossed into salads, such as the endive salad (this page), alongside grilled foods, or with the shawarma cauli ower (this page).

recipes.title: Feta dumplings with fresh chile sauce
recipes.description: These dumplings are all at once comforting, tangy, spicy, and decadent. ’ The sauce is based on shattah, a fermented Palestinian chile sauce. Weve shortcut the process by adding some vinegar for sharpness and fresh tomato to counterbalance the spice. Yotam admits to always having a jar of ‘ ’ it in his fridge, to spoon on to just about anything that needs a grown-up twist. Make this kid-friendly by serving the chile sauce on the side.
ingredients_raw: 1 tbsp/200g whole-milk ricotta, drained of any water
1½ oz/40g pecorino romano, roughly grated (⅓ cup)
3 cups plus ½ cup/130g fine semolina
3¼ oz/90g Fresno chiles, stems discarded, then roughly chopped, seeds and all
1 large plum or vine tomato (3½ oz/100g), quartered

instructions: 1. Put the feta, ricotta, pecorino, and teaspoon of salt into a food processor and pulse just a couple of times, until it looks like cottage cheese. Transfer to a bowl and stir in the egg, yolk, our, and ⅓ cup/50g of the semolina. ½

2. Place the remaining cup/80g of semolina in a bowl and keep a medium baking sheet beside you. Use your hands to shape the feta mixture ¼ into ping-pong-size balls, each weighing roughly 1 oz/35g. Coat each ball well in the semolina, then transfer to the sheet and continue with the rest. You should make 16 in total. Sprinkle any semolina left in the bowl over the ½ ’ feta balls on the sheet, then refrigerate for 1 hours, or overnight if you re getting ahead.

3. Meanwhile, make the fresh chile sauce. Put the chiles and 1 teaspoon of salt into a food processor and pulse a few times until nely chopped. Add the tomato and vinegar and pulse a few more times, just enough to break down the tomatoes. Transfer to a bowl and stir in the oil.

4. Bring a large pot of water to a boil on medium-high heat. Turn the heat down to medium-low so that the water is barely bubbling. Carefully drop the dumplings one at a time into the water and cook for 18 minutes (the water ’ won t be simmering at all). They will have risen to the surface, but do give them the full 18 minutes to ensure they cook through. Use a slotted spoon to gently transfer them to a baking sheet lined with paper towels. ¼

5. Toward the last 10 minutes, put the cinnamon, butter, and teaspoon of salt into a medium sauté pan over medium-high heat. Once the butter has melted, cook for 4 minutes, swirling the pan occasionally, or until the butter is lightly browned and smells nutty.

6. Transfer the dumplings to a large shallow platter with a lip, then pour in – the cinnamon butter. Spoon 3 4 tablespoons of the chile sauce over the top, serving any extra alongside. Fresh chile sauce – ’ You ll make more than you need; place in a sterilized jar, seal it with a little olive oil, and keep in the fridge for up to 2 weeks. – This sauce is one to serve at almost every mealtime, to spoon on to anything that needs a bit of a kick.

recipes.title: ’ Green minestrone with cheat's preserved lemon
recipes.description: This soup lands somewhere between a Persian herb soup (ash-e reshteh) — and an Italian minestrone an asheroni, Noor calls it. Whatever you name it, the important thing is to use an abundance of soft herbs (use more or less of what you like and have on hand), your favorite canned beans (chickpeas would work well), and any kind of little pasta shape you fancy (macaroni or ’ orzo, for example). The cheats preserved lemon gives the whole dish a sour tang, but to save time you could always just stir in some chopped store- bought preserved lemon or nish it off with a squeeze of lemon juice. –

4. Make the chile oil by putting the remaining 3 tablespoons of oil into a small frying pan and placing it over medium-high heat. Once hot, but not ¾ smoking, remove from the heat and immediately add the remaining teaspoon of chile akes (it should sizzle). Set aside. –

5. When ready to serve, divide the soup among 4 6 bowls and top each ’ with a small spoonful or two of the cheats preserved lemon and a good drizzle of the chile oil, making sure to mix the paste in before eating. recipes.title: ’ Double lemon chicken with cheat's preserved lemon
recipes.description: The universally loved crispy chicken is found in multiple corners of the world and is served on multiple tables, from Austrian schnitzel to Korean fried “ ” ’ chicken to the highly Westernized lemon chicken that you d get at your local Chinese restaurant. The latter is the inspiration for this dish, in which a sweet lemony sauce coats crispy fried chicken pieces. This version uses a ’ cheats preserved lemon paste and plenty of fresh lemon to brighten it all up. Serve this with the broccolini with peanut gochujang dressing (this page) and/or the fragrant coconut rice (this page).

2. Meanwhile, in a large bowl whisk together the egg whites, soy sauce, ½ cornstarch, teaspoon of salt, and a good grind of pepper just until there ’ aren t any lumps, about 30 seconds. 4. Heat the sun ower oil in a large high-sided frying pan over medium-high heat. 5. Transfer the chicken breasts to a large serving platter with a lip (cutting them into strips, if you like) and pour the sauce all over. Sprinkle with the remaining cumin. In a small bowl, toss together the green onion, cilantro, and lemon juice and spoon this over the top. recipes.title: Corn nuggets with hot sauce
recipes.description: These nuggets are crispy on the outside and melty on the inside, making ’ them really quite snackable. The vinegary hot sauce is just whats needed to ’ cut through the rich cheesiness of the nuggets, but its also great to have in ’ the fridge to drizzle over anything that needs a spicy kick. You ll make more than you need; see the box below for storage information.

2. Squeeze as much moisture from the corn as possible. Transfer to a cutting board and roughly chop the kernels, then add the corn and the cheese mixture to the our bowl and mix to combine. Set aside for 15 minutes to settle. ¼– ½ –

4. Meanwhile, make the hot sauce. Put the chiles, garlic, vinegar, sugar, and ½ teaspoon of salt into a small saucepan and place it on medium-high heat. Bring to a simmer and cook for 3 minutes, then remove from the heat and let cool completely. Transfer to a food processor (or blender) along with the olive oil and water and blitz until completely smooth, scraping down the sides of the bowl as needed. Strain through a sieve set over a bowl, discarding the solids.

5. When ready to fry, heat the sun ower oil in a medium saucepan on medium-high heat. Test if the oil is hot enough by sprinkling in some — fi polenta it should sizzle immediately. 6. Serve the nuggets warm, with the hot sauce in a bowl alongside. Hot sauce – Store refrigerated in a sterilized jar or glass bottle for up to 2 months. – Hot sauce on everything, really: eggs, toast, rice, potatoes, and more!

recipes.description: Pickling time: 2 hours to overnight This pickle is super special on its own: keep a jar in the fridge to spoon on to a baked potato or spread inside a grilled cheese. Be sure to start making the recipe the day before, allowing the pickle to settle in the fridge overnight fl ’ (the avors only improve with time). Here its served with yogurt, to be eaten as a mezze with atbreads, but this is optional. Use a dairy-free yogurt to keep it vegan.

recipes.title: ’ Beets with charred green onions, za'atar, and feta cream
recipes.description: ’ The story goes that beets, feta, and zaatar met up once, had a party and ’ have been inseparable ever since. We can t blame them really; these three musketeers work together so wonderfully, whichever form they take. Here ’ they re joined by charred lemon and green onions, which they welcome ’ with open arms. Theres very little effort involved in cooking your own beets, but if you want to save time, then feel free to use pre-cooked, store-bought beets.

recipes.description: This bake was born out of a fridge clearout, and is a great way to use up any root vegetables you might have on hand. Whatever the combination, just keep the total net weight of root veggies the same. Veganize this hearty main by swapping out the chicken stock for vegetable stock and using a non-dairy yogurt for the tahini sauce. We love using our own homemade dukkah, an Egyptian spiced seed and nut mix, but you can just as easily use store-bought. If you are indeed making your own, feel free to play around with it, customizing the dukkah according to what you have in your cupboards!

recipes.description: Coconut oss is a spiced coconut condiment popular in Indonesia, Singapore, and Malaysia. Typically it is served with rice and has a much more extensive ingredient list, including tamarind, lemongrass, galangal, and various other tropical delights. This streamlined version is a simpli ed take on the original. It works well sprinkled onto salad or rice dishes. Serve this with some seared shrimp or grilled sh for a complete meal.

Yes, that ” sounds about right. They taste. The lemon wedges are squeezed. Optional, of course, but also essential. ’ Its not that every dish needs an abundance of herbs, or even lots of lemon, ’ to make it sing. Its more about adding that extra oomph where needed, where notes once at become sharp and harmonious. In the culinary game, your trick of the trade will be mastering this balancing act, where something — — rich crispy roasted beans bathed in brown butter will require something fresh: a lemony green onion pesto. Noor, so con dent that olive oil would win, did a team tally and found that, actually, the Test Kitchen is split down the middle. Yotam, Gitai, Tara, and Noor are all faithfully team olive oil, and Verena, Clodagh, Chaya, and Jens are all audaciously team butter. Needless to say, this was quite heartbreaking for the olive oil team, who feel slightly betrayed by their “ ’ fi peers: Isn t it an unspoken rule that we nish all our dishes with a good ” drizzle of oil? said the very aghast team olive oil. Alas, the conversation continues, as is the nature of the Test Kitchen, lots and lots of conversations revolving around one shared goal: making good food with good ingredients, with or without olive oil. ’ ’ In an ideal world, you d use a mixture of both, says Verena, and shes not wrong. The two combined make for a wonderful mouth-feel, as is the case for the roasted hake with fenugreek onions (this page), where the onions are cooked until meltingly soft in both fats, alongside fenugreek and all its spicy friends. This creates a rich topping for the sh, which is then baked in a smidge more butter and oil, for a very delightful experience. As the title suggests, this chapter is all about the multitude of ways in which we use oil to avor food (no shade toward team butter, of course). ’ Sometimes its via infusion, as with the smoky chipotle oil (pictured on this page) made to eat alongside the black lime focaccia (this page). Sliced garlic and chipotle chile akes are fried together with the oil, so you get crispy bits and spicy bits throughout, and a striking orange-red oil to dip the bread in. At times the process is much more straightforward, as with the parsley oil spooned over the charred green pepper and bulgur pilaf (this page). The fresh parsley is blitzed with oil and garlic, and used to brighten an otherwise comforting meal. The elephant in the room is of course the saffron water (this page), not an oil at all but rather liquid gold that rightfully ’ deserves a grand seat on anyones shelves. We added it here as, just like a ’ figood drizzle of oil, its very much a nishing touch. In this case, we spoon it onto baked orzo and caramelized fennel, the saffron adding a golden hue to the whole dish. Regardless of where your loyalties lie on the olive oil vs butter debate ’ fi (theres room for both, of course!), we hope you nd inspiration in this chapter, and the numerous extras that come with it. ’
